title: Project-Based Learning Design to Enhance Middle School Computer Science Education and Interest

context.prior_knowledge: Expert-level knowledge and experience in solving complex problems
context.additional_context: STEM education enhancement using unplugged activities and play robots in digital device-provided environments

learning_goals: Learners can explain core concepts of computer science through unplugged activities

In 4-member teams, learners complete an 8-week playable robot project (obstacle-avoidance robot), fulfilling three stages: (1) deriving ≥3 core requirements in problem definition, (2) sketching ≥2 solutions and co-designing with tools like Figma, (3) conducting ≥3 prototype improvement tests, and submitting a final demonstration meeting ≥4 out of 5 rubric criteria (≥80%).

Learners select one gender-specific STEM topic (e.g., robotics for females, data science for males) from three options, conduct a 4-week inquiry, submit a computer science project, and achieve ≥4 points (5-point scale) in a satisfaction survey to confirm sustained interest.

Learners use digital tools (sensors, data analysis software) to select one real-world problem (e.g., energy conservation, safety management), divide the solution process into five stages (problem definition, data collection, analysis, solution design, evaluation), and complete a 5–10-page project report or 10-minute presentation.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
